title: Restructure existing page markup into semantic HTML containers without changing content

requirements.text: Refactor the existing page markup to use a fully semantic layout by placing the current content into appropriate HTML5 semantic containers (at minimum: <header>, <main>, and <footer>), while keeping all existing content completely unchanged.

quotes: A) Generate the fully restructured HTML with every section placed in the correct semantic container (no content touched)

acceptanceCriteria: The resulting markup includes <header>, <main>, and <footer> elements and uses additional semantic elements where appropriate (e.g., <nav>, <section>, <article>, <aside>) without changing the content.
All user-visible text remains identical (no edits, no rewording, no additions/removals).
All existing attributes (including id, class, data-*, aria-*), links/URLs, form fields, and inline styles (if any) are preserved exactly.
All existing scripts and functional hooks (event handlers, element IDs used by JS, form names) continue to work identically after the restructure.
Content order remains the same as before; changes are limited to adding/moving semantic wrapper containers and grouping elements semantically.

constraints: Do not change, add, or remove any content (text, images, links, form fields).
Do not change styling (class names, inline styles) or behavior; only restructure DOM using semantic containers.
Do not modify immutable frontend paths listed in SYSTEM_CONTEXT; compose around them if needed.
nonGoals: Creating new pages, routes, or app features beyond semantic restructuring.
Updating copy, branding, colors, typography, spacing, or any visual redesign.
Changing backend logic or adding backend endpoints.
